Episode IDs can be obtained from search_for_item with `type=\\\"episode\\\"` (format as spotify:episode:ID URIs).\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Append tracks: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", uris=[\\\"spotify:track:track1\\\", \\\"spotify:track:track2\\\"]`\\n- Add podcast episode: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", uris=[\\\"spotify:episode:episode1\\\"]`\\n- Mix tracks and episodes: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", uris=[\\\"spotify:track:track1\\\", \\\"spotify:episode:episode1\\\", \\\"spotify:track:track2\\\"]`\\n- Insert at start: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", uris=[\\\"spotify:track:track1\\\"], position=0`\\n- Insert at position: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", uris=[\\\"spotify:episode:episode1\\\"], position=5`\\n\\n**State Changes:** Adds the specified tracks and/or episodes to the playlist's playlist_tracks items array, or inserts them at the requested position. Generates new snapshot_id. Each item includes added_at timestamp and added_by user reference.\\n\\n**Returns:** New snapshot_id only.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:** Duplicate tracks and episodes can be added.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>remove_playlist_items</summary>\\n\\nRemoves one or more tracks or episodes from a playlist by URI, removing ALL occurrences if duplicates exist.\\n\\nTrack/episode IDs must be alphanumeric-only to work with this tool.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `playlist_id` (required): The Spotify playlist ID\\n\\u2022 `tracks` (required): Array of objects, each with `uri` field (e.g., [{\\\"uri\\\": \\\"spotify:track:...\\\"}] or [{\\\"uri\\\": \\\"spotify:episode:...\\\"}]) (maximum 100)\\n\\u2022 `snapshot_id` (optional): Playlist snapshot ID - include to confirm that other users have not modified the playlist since the agent last accessed it (for collaborative playlists)\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Playlist ID can be obtained from e.g. get_current_users_playlists. Track and episode URIs can be obtained from get_playlist_items (format as spotify:track:ID or spotify:episode:ID).\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Remove tracks: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", tracks=[{\\\"uri\\\": \\\"spotify:track:track1\\\"}, {\\\"uri\\\": \\\"spotify:track:track2\\\"}]`\\n- Remove episode: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", tracks=[{\\\"uri\\\": \\\"spotify:episode:episode1\\\"}]`\\n- Mix removal: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", tracks=[{\\\"uri\\\": \\\"spotify:track:track1\\\"}, {\\\"uri\\\": \\\"spotify:episode:episode1\\\"}]`\\n- With snapshot check: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", tracks=[{\\\"uri\\\": \\\"...\\\"}], snapshot_id=\\\"snapshot_abc\\\"`\\n\\n**State Changes:** Removes ALL occurrences of the specified track and episode URIs from the playlist's items array. Generates new snapshot_id. Decrements total item count.\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with new snapshot_id only. Changes can be confirmed by calling get_playlist.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:**\\n* Idempotent - removing non-existent items doesn't error.\\n* The call will fail if the current snapshot_id of the playlist does not match the one provided in the snapshot_id parameter, indicating that another user has modified the playlist already. In this case, the agent will need to call get_playlist to get an updated snapshot_id, then retry the call to this function with that new id.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>update_playlist_items</summary>\\n\\nThis tool can perform one of two actions within a single call:\\n* replace ALL tracks in a playlist with a new list (when including uris)\\n\\nOR\\n* reorder existing tracks (when using range/insert)\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `playlist_id` (required): The Spotify playlist ID\\n\\u2022 `uris` (optional): Array of Spotify URIs to REPLACE all tracks (maximum 100)\\n\\u2022 `range_start` (optional): Starting position of range to reorder\\n\\u2022 `insert_before` (optional): Position to insert reordered range before\\n\\u2022 `range_length` (optional): Length of range to reorder (default 1)\\n\\u2022 `snapshot_id` (optional): Playlist snapshot ID - include to confirm that other users have not modified the playlist since the agent last accessed it (for collaborative playlists)\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Playlist ID can be obtained from e.g. create_playlist or get_current_users_playlists. Track URIs for replacement can be obtained from search_for_item or other track-returning tools.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Replace all tracks: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", uris=[\\\"spotify:track:track1\\\", \\\"spotify:track:track2\\\"]`\\n- Reorder: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", range_start=3, insert_before=0, range_length=2` (moves tracks 3-4 to start)\\n\\n**State Changes:**\\n* If uris provided: COMPLETELY REPLACES all tracks with new list, generates new snapshot_id.\\n* If only reorder params provided: Reorders tracks within the existing list, generates new snapshot_id.\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with new snapshot_id string.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:** \\n* `uris` takes precendence - if both uris and reordering parameters are included, the tool will ignore the reordering parameters and just perform the replace action.\\n* DESTRUCTIVE when using uris - replaces entire playlist content. Use add_items_to_playlist to append instead.\\n* The call will fail if the current snapshot_id of the playlist does not match the one provided in the snapshot_id parameter, indicating that another user has modified the playlist already. In this case, the agent will need to call get_playlist to get an updated snapshot_id, then retry the call to this function with that new id.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>change_playlist_details</summary>\\n\\nModifies a playlist's name, description, and public/collaborative settings.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `playlist_id` (required): The Spotify playlist ID\\n\\u2022 `name` (optional): New playlist name\\n\\u2022 `public` (optional): Change public/private status\\n\\u2022 `collaborative` (optional): Change collaborative status. Collaborative playlists must be private (public=false).\\n\\u2022 `description` (optional): Update description text\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Playlist ID can be obtained from e.g. create_playlist or get_current_users_playlists.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Rename playlist: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", name=\\\"Updated Name\\\"`\\n- Make private: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", public=false`\\n- Update all metadata: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", name=\\\"New Name\\\", description=\\\"New desc\\\", public=false`\\n- Make collaborative: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", collaborative=true` (must also set public=false)\\n\\n**State Changes:** Updates the specified fields in the playlist object. Generates new snapshot_id. Other fields remain unchanged if not specified.\\n\\n**Returns:** Empty object {} (no success message). Changes can be confirmed by calling get_playlist.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:** Only specified fields are updated, others remain unchanged.  \\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>add_custom_playlist_cover_image</summary>\\n\\nUploads a custom JPEG image to use as the cover for a playlist, replacing any existing image.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `playlist_id` (required): The Spotify playlist ID\\n\\u2022 `image_data` (required): Base64-encoded JPEG image data (maximum 256 KB after decoding)\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Playlist ID can be obtained from e.g. create_playlist or get_current_users_playlists. Image must be JPEG format and under 256 KB when decoded.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Set custom cover: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", image_data=\\\"<base64-encoded-jpeg>\\\"`\\n- Replace existing cover: Same call replaces previous image\\n\\n**State Changes:** Updates playlist_cover_images collection with new image data. Replaces any previous custom cover. Does not change snapshot_id (cover image changes don't affect playlist version).\\n\\n**Returns:** None (no response body). Confirm changes by calling get_playlist_cover_image.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n</details>\\n\"}", "html_preview_b_db": "the initial world state for task #1", "html_preview_a": "<!DOCTYPE html>\n    <html Dreams</li>\\n<li>NMR: Charli XCX - Apple</li>\\n<li>NMR: Sabrina Carpenter - Espresso</li>\\n</ol>\", \"representation\": \"storage\"}}, \"version\": {\"number\": 1, \"minorEdit\": false}, \"history\": {\"latest\": true, \"createdBy\": {\"type\": \"known\", \"username\": \"system\", \"displayName\": \"System User\"}, \"createdDate\": \"2025-12-29T14:00:00.000Z\"}, \"_links\": {\"self\": \"/wiki/rest/api/content/8\"}}}, \"long_task_counter\": 1, \"content_labels\": {}, \"long_tasks\": {}, \"spaces\": {\"NMR\": {\"name\": \"New Music Research\", \"description\": \"Central knowledge base for the New Music Research division. Weekly trends, cultural impact reports, and marketing playbooks.\", \"spaceKey\": \"NMR\"}}, \"content_counter\": 9, \"deleted_spaces_tasks\": {}}, \"timezoneOffset\": \"-05:00\"},\n                    propsJsonPrev: null,\n                    bundleUrl: \"https://agent-tools-11866-a72f0a4c-vrd7x608.onporter.run/static/bundle.js\",\n                    docsRaw: \"<style>\\ndetails summary {\\n    padding: 8px;\\n    border-radius: 4px;\\n    margin: 4px 0;\\n    cursor: pointer;\\n    font-weight: bold;\\n}\\ndetails[open] {\\n    border: 1px solid #ddd;\\n    border-radius: 4px;\\n    padding: 8px;\\n    margin: 8px 0;\\n}\\ndetails details {\\n    margin-left: 16px;\\n    border-left: 2px solid #ddd;\\n    padding-left: 8px;\\n}\\n.overview { background-color: #d8eeffff; }\\n.documentation { background-color: #fbe9ffff; }\\n.data-structure { background-color: #fbefffff; border-left: 3px solid #6c757d; }\\n.read-tools { background-color: #dcffe0ff; }\\n.write-tools { background-color: #ffe8c2ff; }\\n.tool { background-color: #f8f9fa; border-left: 3px solid #6c757d; }\\n</style>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"overview\\\">\\n<summary>\\ud83d\\udd0d Service Overview</summary>\\n\\nThis service simulates Atlassian Confluence's API for managing collaborative documentation, knowledge bases, and content organization. It includes pages, blog posts, comments, spaces, and long-running task tracking.\\n\\n**Key Features:**\\n- **Content Management**: Create, edit, and organize pages, blog posts, comments, and limited attachments with versioning and HTML storage.\\n- **Spaces**: Organize content into logical groupings with public and private spaces supporting custom descriptions\\n- **Search & Discovery**: Powerful CQL (Confluence Query Language) search with support for complex queries\\n- **Hierarchy & Relations**: Parent-child relations, comments on pages, and descendant tracking for building content trees\\n- **Labels & Properties**: Flexible tagging system with custom labels and properties for metadata management\\n- **Content Body Conversion**: Convert content between different representation formats (storage, view, export_view, editor)\\n- **Long-Running Tasks**: Track asynchronous operations like space deletion and content migration\\n- **Attachments: Supported with major limitations.**\\n\\n**High-Level Usage Patterns:**\\n- Create and manage wiki pages and blog posts with rich HTML content\\n- Search content using CQL queries with complex filtering and date ranges\\n- Build hierarchical documentation with pages, child pages, and comments\\n- Tag and categorize content with labels for easy discovery\\n- Track content versions and history for audit trails\\n\\n**Default Example DB Overview:**\\nThe default database contains 3 spaces (DOC, BLOG, MARKETING), 7 content items including 3 pages, 2 blog posts, and 2 comments. Content demonstrates various states (current, draft, trashed), version tracking, HTML body storage, comment ancestors, and posting dates for blog posts. The database includes 5 content properties, 7 label collections, 5 long-running tasks, and 5 space deletion tasks showing different statuses (in_progress, completed, failed).\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"documentation\\\">\\n<summary>\\ud83d\\udcda Detailed Documentation</summary>\\n\\n## Core Concepts\\n\\n### Spaces\\nSpaces provide organizational containers for related content:\\n- Each space has a unique key (e.g., \\\"DOC\\\", \\\"MARKETING\\\") and descriptive name\\n- Spaces can be public (default) or private with restricted access\\n- All content must belong to a space - the space key is required for content creation\\n- Space deletion is tracked as a long-running task due to cascading operations\\n\\n### Content Items\\nConfluence content represents individual pieces of information with support for multiple types:\\n- **Pages**: Standard documentation with hierarchical relationships and rich HTML content\\n- **Blog Posts**: Time-stamped with posting dates for announcements and updates\\n- **Comments**: Discussion and feedback attached to pages or blog posts\\n\\n**Content Status**: Each content item has a status indicating its lifecycle stage:\\n- `current`: Active and visible content\\n- `draft`: Work in progress, not yet published\\n- `trashed`: Soft-deleted content that can be restored\\n- `archived`: Historical content preserved for reference\\n- `historical`: Previous versions of content\\n\\nVersion numbers are automatically tracked with each update, along with flags for minor edits and timestamps.\\n\\n### Content Body Formats\\nContent body supports multiple representation formats:\\n- **storage**: Raw HTML format stored in the database (e.g., `<p>Welcome to our docs!</p>`)\\n- **view**: Rendered HTML for display to users\\n- **export_view**: HTML optimized for export operations\\n- **editor**: Format suitable for editing interfaces\\n\\n### Labels & Properties\\nFully modifiable system for organizing and annotating content:\\n- **Labels**: String tags applied to content for categorization (e.g., \\\"important\\\", \\\"marketing\\\", \\\"api\\\")\\n- **Properties**: Key-value pairs storing structured metadata with versioning support\\n\\n### Attachments\\nAttachments have significant limitations in this service, as new files cannot currently be uploaded, and some tools are not fully operational.\\n\\n**Initial context:** You can describe attachments in your initial context!\\n\\n**Search:** Any existing fields can be viewed by a search with `get_content_attachments` or other content search/list/get operations, but attachment content is not searched nor readable.\\n\\n**Create:** Not supported.\\n\\n**Edit:** You can edit the attachment\\u2019s metadata with `update_attachment_data` and `update_content`. However, the `update_attachment` tool is not currently supported.\\n\\n\\n### Long-Running Tasks\\nAsynchronous operations tracked as tasks with status (in_progress, completed, failed) separately from the content itself. Common uses include space deletion, content migration, indexing, and cache rebuilding.\\n\\n**Can only create space deletion tasks, which will be immediately marked as \\\"complete\\\" in this simulation.**\\n\\n### CQL (Confluence Query Language)\\nPowerful query language for searching content with support for:\\n- **Field Operators**: `=`, `!=`, `~` (contains), `!~` (not contains), `>`, `<`, `>=`, `<=`\\n- **Logical Operators**: `AND`, `OR`, `NOT` (case-insensitive)\\n- **Searchable Fields**: type, space/spaceKey, title, status, id, text, created, postingDay, label\\n- **Functions**: `now()`, `now('-4w')`, `now('+1d')` for relative date filtering\\n- **Text Search**: The `text` field searches across title, body content, and labels\\n- **Examples**:\\n  - `type='page' AND space='DOC'`\\n  - `title~'meeting' OR title~'notes'`\\n  - `created>now('-4w') AND status='current'`\\n  - `label='important' AND type='page'`\\n\\n<details class=\\\"data-structure\\\">\\n<summary>Database Structure</summary> \\n\\nThe Confluence database has seven root collections for managing all content and metadata:\\n\\n<details class=\\\"data-structure\\\">\\n<summary>spaces</summary>\\n\\nDictionary of space objects indexed by space key (e.g., `\\\"DOC\\\"`, `\\\"MARKETING\\\"`). Spaces organize content into logical groups.\\n\\n**Space Object:**\\n\\n**`spaceKey`**: (Required) Unique space identifier string in uppercase (e.g., `\\\"DOC\\\"`, `\\\"BLOG\\\"`, `\\\"MARKETING\\\"`).\\n\\n**`name`**: (Required) Display name string for the space (e.g., `\\\"Documentation Space\\\"`, `\\\"Marketing\\\"`).\\n\\n**`description`**: (Optional) Description string or null. Explains the space's purpose (e.g., `\\\"All official documentation\\\"`, `\\\"Marketing strategies and campaigns\\\"`).\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"data-structure\\\">\\n<summary>contents</summary>\\n\\nDictionary of content objects indexed by content ID (e.g., `\\\"1\\\"`, `\\\"2\\\"`). Stores all pages, blog posts, comments, and attachments with complete metadata.\\n\\n**Content Object:**\\n\\n**`id`**: (Required) Unique string identifier for the content (e.g., `\\\"1\\\"`).\\n\\n**`type`**: (Required) Content type - `\\\"page\\\"`, `\\\"blogpost\\\"`, `\\\"comment\\\"`, or `\\\"attachment\\\"`.\\n\\n**`spaceKey`**: (Required) Key of the space containing this content (e.g., `\\\"DOC\\\"`, `\\\"MARKETING\\\"`).\\n\\n**`title`**: (Required) Display title of the content (e.g., `\\\"Home Page\\\"`, `\\\"Strategy Plan\\\"`).\\n\\n**`status`**: (Required) Content status - `\\\"current\\\"`, `\\\"draft\\\"`, `\\\"trashed\\\"`, `\\\"archived\\\"`, or `\\\"historical\\\"`.\\n\\n**`body`**: (Required) Nested object containing content body:\\n- `storage`: (Required) Object with HTML storage format:\\n  - `value`: (Required) The actual HTML content string (e.g., `\\\"<p>Welcome to our docs!</p>\\\"`)\\n  - `representation`: (Required) Format type, always `\\\"storage\\\"`\\n\\n**`version`**: (Required) Version tracking object:\\n- `number`: (Required) Integer version number, increments with each update (e.g., `1`, `2`)\\n- `minorEdit`: (Required) Boolean indicating whether the update was minor\\n\\n**`history`**: (Required) Historical metadata object:\\n- `latest`: (Required) Boolean indicating if this is the latest version (`true` for current version)\\n- `createdBy`: (Required) Creator information object:\\n  - `type`: (Required) User type, typically `\\\"known\\\"` or `\\\"anonymous\\\"`\\n  - `username`: (Required) Username string (e.g., `\\\"admin\\\"`, `\\\"product_manager\\\"`)\\n  - `displayName`: (Required) Friendly display name (e.g., `\\\"Admin User\\\"`, `\\\"Product Manager\\\"`)\\n- `createdDate`: (Required) ISO 8601 timestamp of creation (e.g., `\\\"2024-01-01T10:00:00.000Z\\\"`)\\n\\n**`_links`**: (Required) API navigation links object:\\n- `self`: (Required) Self-reference URL string (e.g., `\\\"/wiki/rest/api/content/1\\\"`)\\n\\n**`ancestors`**: (Optional) Array of ancestor references, required for comments. Each ancestor is an object:\\n- `id`: (Required) String ID of the parent content (e.g., `\\\"1\\\"`)\\n\\n**`postingDay`**: (Optional) String date for blog posts in YYYY-MM-DD format (e.g., `\\\"2024-01-15\\\"`). Not present for pages or comments.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"data-structure\\\">\\n<summary>content_counter</summary>\\n\\nInteger counter for generating unique content IDs. Increments after each content creation. Example: `8` means next content will have ID `\\\"8\\\"`.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"data-structure\\\">\\n<summary>content_properties</summary>\\n\\nDictionary of content property objects indexed by property ID. Stores custom key-value metadata attached to content items.\\n\\n**ContentProperty Object:**\\n\\n**`key`**: (Required) Unique property key string (e.g., `\\\"author\\\"`, `\\\"views\\\"`, `\\\"category\\\"`).\\n\\n**`value`**: (Required) Property value of any JSON-serializable type (string, number, object, array, etc.). Examples: `\\\"Alice\\\"`, `150`, `\\\"High\\\"`.\\n\\n**`version`**: (Required) Integer version number for property updates, starts at `1` and increments.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"data-structure\\\">\\n<summary>content_labels</summary>\\n\\nDictionary mapping content IDs to arrays of label strings. Keys are content IDs (e.g., `\\\"1\\\"`, `\\\"5\\\"`), values are arrays of label strings.\\n\\n**Example**: `\\\"1\\\": [\\\"important\\\", \\\"project\\\", \\\"overview\\\"]`\\n\\nEach content item can have multiple labels for categorization and filtering.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"data-structure\\\">\\n<summary>long_tasks</summary>\\n\\nDictionary of long-running task objects indexed by task ID. Tracks asynchronous operations like migrations and indexing.\\n\\n**LongTask Object:**\\n\\n**`id`**: (Required) Unique task identifier string (e.g., `\\\"1\\\"`, `\\\"2\\\"`).\\n\\n**`status`**: (Required) Task status - `\\\"in_progress\\\"`, `\\\"completed\\\"`, or `\\\"failed\\\"`.\\n\\n**`description`**: (Required) Human-readable task description string (e.g., `\\\"Content migration\\\"`, `\\\"Rebuilding cache\\\"`).\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"data-structure\\\">\\n<summary>long_task_counter</summary>\\n\\nInteger counter for generating unique task IDs. Increments after each task creation. Example: `6` means next task will have ID `\\\"6\\\"`.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"data-structure\\\">\\n<summary>deleted_spaces_tasks</summary>\\n\\nDictionary of space deletion task objects indexed by task ID. Tracks space deletion operations as they complete.\\n\\n**DeletedSpaceTask Object:**\\n\\n**`key`**: (Required) String key of the deleted or deleting space (e.g., `\\\"OLD_PROJECT\\\"`, `\\\"ARCHIVED\\\"`).\\n\\n**`status`**: (Required) Deletion status - `\\\"complete\\\"`, `\\\"in_progress\\\"`, or `\\\"failed\\\"`.\\n\\n**`description`**: (Required) Human-readable description of the deletion task (e.g., `\\\"Deleted old project space\\\"`, `\\\"Archiving old data\\\"`).\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"read-tools\\\">\\n<summary>\\ud83d\\udcd6 Read-Only Tools</summary>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_content_details</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves a single content item by its unique ID. Returns complete content metadata including title, body, version, history, and relationships.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): String content ID to retrieve (e.g., `\\\"1\\\"`, `\\\"5\\\"`)\\n\\u2022 `status` (optional): Filter by expected status. If provided, content must match this status or an error is raised. Use `\\\"any\\\"` to bypass status checking\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `id` must be obtained from a previous call to `get_content_list`, `search_content`, or another content retrieval function.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get page by ID: `id: \\\"1\\\"`\\n- Get content regardless of status: `id: \\\"4\\\", status: \\\"any\\\"`\\n- Verify content is current: `id: \\\"2\\\", status: \\\"current\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Complete content object with id, type, spaceKey, title, status, body (storage format), version, history, _links, and optional ancestors (for comments) or postingDay (for blog posts).\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_content_list</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves a paginated list of content items with optional filtering by type, space, title, status, and posting date.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `type` (optional): Filter by content type - `\\\"page\\\"`, `\\\"blogpost\\\"`, `\\\"comment\\\"`, or `\\\"attachment\\\"`\\n\\u2022 `spaceKey` (optional): Filter by space key (e.g., `\\\"DOC\\\"`, `\\\"MARKETING\\\"`)\\n\\u2022 `title` (optional): Filter by exact title match\\n\\u2022 `status` (optional, default `\\\"current\\\"`): Filter by status - `\\\"current\\\"`, `\\\"draft\\\"`, `\\\"trashed\\\"`, `\\\"archived\\\"`, `\\\"historical\\\"`, or `\\\"any\\\"` for all statuses\\n\\u2022 `postingDay` (optional): Filter blog posts by posting date in YYYY-MM-DD format\\n\\u2022 `expand` (optional): Comma-separated fields to expand (not currently used)\\n\\u2022 `start` (optional, default 0): Pagination offset (non-negative integer)\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional, default 25): Maximum results to return (positive integer)\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- List all current content: No parameters needed (defaults to status=\\\"current\\\")\\n- List all pages in DOC space: `type: \\\"page\\\", spaceKey: \\\"DOC\\\"`\\n- List blog posts from specific date: `type: \\\"blogpost\\\", postingDay: \\\"2024-03-15\\\"`\\n- Paginate results: `start: 10, limit: 5`\\n\\n**Returns:** Array of content objects matching the filter criteria.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>search_content</summary>\\n\\nSearches content using CQL (Confluence Query Language) with support for complex queries, filtering, and field expansion.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `query` (required): CQL query string with support for field operators (=, !=, ~, !~, >, <, >=, <=), logical operators (AND, OR, NOT), and functions (now())\\n\\u2022 `expand` (optional): Comma-separated fields to expand - `\\\"space\\\"`, `\\\"version\\\"`, `\\\"body\\\"`, `\\\"body.storage\\\"`, `\\\"body.view\\\"`, `\\\"metadata\\\"`, `\\\"metadata.labels\\\"`, `\\\"history\\\"`, `\\\"ancestors\\\"`, `\\\"container\\\"`\\n\\u2022 `start` (optional, default 0): Pagination offset (non-negative)\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional, default 25): Maximum results (1-1000)\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Find pages in DOC space: `query: \\\"type='page' AND space='DOC'\\\"`\\n- Search by title keyword: `query: \\\"title~'meeting'\\\"`\\n- Find recent content: `query: \\\"created>now('-4w') AND status='current'\\\"`\\n- Search text across fields: `query: \\\"text~'marketing' AND type='page'\\\"`\\n- Combine filters: `query: \\\"type='page' AND space='DOC' AND title~'Home'\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Array of content objects matching the CQL query. Expanded fields are added when requested.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>search_content_cql</summary>\\n\\nAlternative search interface using CQL syntax. Functionally identical to `search_content` but follows Confluence REST API naming convention.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `cql` (required): CQL query string (same syntax as search_content)\\n\\u2022 `expand` (optional): Fields to expand\\n\\u2022 `start` (optional, default 0): Pagination offset\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional, default 25): Maximum results\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Same as search_content but using `cql` parameter name\\n- Search pages: `cql: \\\"type=page AND space=DOC\\\"`\\n- Filter by status: `cql: \\\"status=current AND type!=comment\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Array of matching content objects.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_content_history</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves historical metadata for a content item including creation information and version details.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Content ID to get history for\\n\\u2022 `expand` (optional): Comma-separated fields to expand - `\\\"previousVersion\\\"`, `\\\"nextVersion\\\"`, `\\\"lastUpdated\\\"`\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `id` must be obtained from a previous content retrieval function.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get basic creation details: `id: \\\"1\\\"`\\n- Get all history details: `id: \\\"2\\\", expand: \\\"previousVersion,lastUpdated\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** History object with latest flag, createdBy information (type, username, displayName), and createdDate timestamp.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_content_children</summary>\\n\\nReturns direct children of a content item, grouped by content type. E.g. all pages and comments grouped under a page.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Parent content ID\\n\\u2022 `expand` (optional): Fields to expand (not currently used)\\n\\u2022 `parentVersion` (optional, default 0): Parent version number (not currently used)\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `id` must be obtained from a previous content retrieval function.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get all children: `id: \\\"1\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Dictionary mapping content types to arrays of child content objects (e.g., `{\\\"page\\\": [...], \\\"comment\\\": [...]}`).\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_content_children_by_type</summary>\\n\\nReturns paginated direct children of a specific content type. More targeted than get_content_children when you know the child type. E.g. get only other pages grouped under a given page, or only the comments under that page.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Parent content ID\\n\\u2022 `type` (required): Content type to filter by - `\\\"page\\\"`, `\\\"blogpost\\\"`, `\\\"comment\\\"`, or `\\\"attachment\\\"`\\n\\u2022 `expand` (optional): Fields to expand (not currently used)\\n\\u2022 `start` (optional, default 0): Pagination offset\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional, default 25): Maximum results\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `id` must be obtained from a previous content retrieval function.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get child pages: `id: \\\"1\\\", type: \\\"page\\\"`\\n- Get comments with pagination: `id: \\\"3\\\", type: \\\"comment\\\", start: 0, limit: 10`\\n\\n**Returns:** Array of child content objects of the specified type.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_content_descendants</summary>\\n\\nReturns all descendants of a content item (children, grandchildren, etc.) grouped by type. Performs recursive traversal of the content tree. E.g. All pages, blog posts, comments, and attachments grouped under a space.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Parent content ID\\n\\u2022 `expand` (optional): Fields to expand\\n\\u2022 `start` (optional, default 0): Pagination offset\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional, default 25): Maximum results\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `id` must be obtained from a previous content retrieval function.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get full content tree: `id: \\\"1\\\"`\\n- Paginate descendants: `id: \\\"1\\\", start: 10, limit: 5\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Dictionary mapping content types to arrays of descendant content objects.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_content_descendants_by_type</summary>\\n\\nReturns paginated descendants of a specific content type. Combines type filtering with recursive descendant retrieval.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Parent content ID\\n\\u2022 `type` (required): Content type to filter by\\n\\u2022 `expand` (optional): Fields to expand\\n\\u2022 `start` (optional, default 0): Pagination offset\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional, default 25): Maximum results\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `id` must be obtained from a previous content retrieval function.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get all descendant comments: `id: \\\"1\\\", type: \\\"comment\\\"`\\n- Get descendant pages with pagination: `id: \\\"5\\\", type: \\\"page\\\", limit: 20`\\n\\n**Returns:** Array of descendant content objects of the specified type.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_content_comments</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves comments associated with a content item with support for filtering by location and depth.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Content ID to get comments for\\n\\u2022 `expand` (optional): Fields to expand\\n\\u2022 `parentVersion` (optional, default 0): Parent version number\\n\\u2022 `start` (optional, default 0): Pagination offset\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional, default 25): Maximum results\\n\\u2022 `location` (optional): Comment location filter (not in use)\\n\\u2022 `depth` (optional): Comment depth filter (not in use)\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `id` must be obtained from a previous content retrieval function.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get all comments: `id: \\\"1\\\"`\\n- Paginate comments: `id: \\\"3\\\", start: 0, limit: 10`\\n\\n**Returns:** Dictionary with \\\"results\\\" array containing comment objects and pagination information.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_content_attachments</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves attachments for a content item with optional filename and mediaType filtering. **Returns attachment metadata only - not file content.**\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Content ID to get attachments for\\n\\u2022 `expand` (optional): Fields to expand -- **Not in use.** Will not throw an error if included, but will not return requested fields.\\n\\u2022 `start` (optional, default 0): Pagination offset\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional, default 25): Maximum results (max 1000)\\n\\u2022 `filename` (optional): Filter by exact (case-sensitive) filename match (checks against `title` field)\\n\\u2022 `mediaType` (optional): Filter by MIME type (e.g., \\\"text/plain\\\", \\\"application/pdf\\\")\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `id` must be obtained from a previous content retrieval function.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- List all attachments: `id: \\\"1\\\"`\\n- Find specific file: `id: \\\"2\\\", filename: \\\"document.pdf\\\"`\\n- Filter by type: `id: \\\"3\\\", mediaType: \\\"text/plain\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Dictionary with:\\n- `results`: Array of attachment metadata objects, each containing:\\n  - `id`: Attachment identifier\\n  - `type`: Always \\\"attachment\\\"\\n  - `title`: Filename\\n  - `version`: Object with `by` (user info), `when` (timestamp), `message`, `number`, `minorEdit`\\n  - `container`: Parent content info with `id`, `type`, `title`\\n  - `metadata`: Object with `comment` (description), `mediaType` (MIME type), optional `fileSize`\\n  - `_links`: API navigation links\\n  - `_expandable`: Expandable resource references\\n- `size`: Number of results in array\\n- `_links`: Pagination links\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_content_labels</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves labels (tags) applied to a content item with optional prefix filtering.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Content ID to get labels for\\n\\u2022 `prefix` (optional): Filter labels by prefix string\\n\\u2022 `start` (optional, default 0): Pagination offset\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional, default 200): Maximum results\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `id` must be obtained from a previous content retrieval function.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get all labels: `id: \\\"1\\\"`\\n- Filter by prefix: `id: \\\"5\\\", prefix: \\\"team-\\\"`\\n- Paginate labels: `id: \\\"3\\\", limit: 10`\\n\\n**Returns:** Array of label strings (e.g., `[\\\"important\\\", \\\"project\\\", \\\"overview\\\"]`).\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_content_properties</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves custom properties (key-value metadata) for a content item with pagination support.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Content ID to get properties for\\n\\u2022 `expand` (optional): Fields to expand\\n\\u2022 `start` (optional, default 0): Pagination offset\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional, default 10): Maximum results\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `id` must be obtained from a previous content retrieval function.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- List all properties: `id: \\\"1\\\"`\\n- Paginate properties: `id: \\\"2\\\", start: 0, limit: 5`\\n\\n**Returns:** Array of property objects, each containing key, value, and version fields.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_content_property_details</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves a specific property by its key from a content item.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Content ID containing the property\\n\\u2022 `key` (required): Property key to retrieve\\n\\u2022 `expand` (optional): Fields to expand\\n\\n**Prerequisites:**\\n* The `id` must be obtained from a previous content retrieval function\\n* The `key` must be obtained from `get_content_properties` or known from previous property creation\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get author property: `id: \\\"1\\\", key: \\\"author\\\"`\\n- Get views count: `id: \\\"2\\\", key: \\\"views\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Property object with key, value, and version fields.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_content_restrictions_by_operation</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves all content restrictions grouped by operation type (read, update, etc.). Returns permission controls for the content.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Content ID to get restrictions for\\n\\u2022 `expand` (optional): Fields to expand\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `id` must be obtained from a previous content retrieval function.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get all restrictions: `id: \\\"1\\\"`\\n- Check permissions: `id: \\\"3\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Dictionary mapping operation types to restriction objects (e.g., `{\\\"read\\\": {...}, \\\"update\\\": {...}}`).\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_content_restrictions_for_operation</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves restrictions for a specific operation on a content item with pagination support.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Content ID to get restrictions for\\n\\u2022 `operationKey` (required): Operation to check - `\\\"read\\\"` or `\\\"update\\\"`\\n\\u2022 `expand` (optional): Fields to expand\\n\\u2022 `start` (optional, default 0): Pagination offset\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional, default 100): Maximum results\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `id` must be obtained from a previous content retrieval function.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Check read permissions: `id: \\\"1\\\", operationKey: \\\"read\\\"`\\n- Check update permissions: `id: \\\"2\\\", operationKey: \\\"update\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Dictionary with restrictions for the specified operation.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_spaces</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves a paginated list of all spaces with optional filtering by space key.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `spaceKey` (optional): Filter by specific space key (e.g., `\\\"DOC\\\"`, `\\\"MARKETING\\\"`)\\n\\u2022 `start` (optional, default 0): Pagination offset\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional, default 25): Maximum results\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- List all spaces: No parameters needed\\n- Get specific space: `spaceKey: \\\"DOC\\\"`\\n- Paginate spaces: `start: 5, limit: 10`\\n\\n**Returns:** Array of space objects, each with spaceKey, name, and description fields.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_space_details</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves detailed information about a specific space by its key.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `spaceKey` (required): Unique space identifier (e.g., `\\\"DOC\\\"`, `\\\"BLOG\\\"`, `\\\"MARKETING\\\"`)\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `spaceKey` can be obtained from `get_spaces` or known from context.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get DOC space details: `spaceKey: \\\"DOC\\\"`\\n- Get MARKETING space: `spaceKey: \\\"MARKETING\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Space object with spaceKey, name, and description fields.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_space_content</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves all content within a specified space with pagination support.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `spaceKey` (required): Space key to retrieve content from\\n\\u2022 `depth` (optional): Content depth filter (not in use)\\n\\u2022 `expand` (optional): Fields to expand\\n\\u2022 `start` (optional, default 0): Pagination offset\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional, default 25): Maximum results\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `spaceKey` can be obtained from `get_spaces` or known from context.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get all content in DOC space: `spaceKey: \\\"DOC\\\"`\\n- Paginate space content: `spaceKey: \\\"MARKETING\\\", start: 10, limit: 20`\\n\\n**Returns:** Array of content objects within the specified space.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_space_content_by_type</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves content of a specific type within a space with pagination support.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `spaceKey` (required): Space key to retrieve content from\\n\\u2022 `type` (required): Content type filter - `\\\"page\\\"`, `\\\"blogpost\\\"`, `\\\"comment\\\"`, or `\\\"attachment\\\"`\\n\\u2022 `depth` (optional): Content depth filter\\n\\u2022 `expand` (optional): Fields to expand\\n\\u2022 `start` (optional, default 0): Pagination offset\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional, default 25): Maximum results\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `spaceKey` can be obtained from `get_spaces` or known from context.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get all pages in DOC space: `spaceKey: \\\"DOC\\\", type: \\\"page\\\"`\\n- Get blog posts in BLOG space: `spaceKey: \\\"BLOG\\\", type: \\\"blogpost\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Array of content objects of the specified type within the space.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_long_tasks</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves a paginated list of all long-running tasks tracked by the system.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `expand` (optional): Fields to expand (not currently processed)\\n\\u2022 `start` (optional, default 0): Pagination offset\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional, default 100): Maximum results\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- List all tasks: No parameters needed\\n- Paginate tasks: `start: 5, limit: 20`\\n\\n**Returns:** Array of task objects with id, status, and description fields.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_long_task_details</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves details for a specific long-running task by its ID.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Task ID to retrieve\\n\\u2022 `expand` (optional): Fields to expand\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `id` should be obtained from `get_long_tasks` or known from task creation.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Check task status: `id: \\\"1\\\"`\\n- Get task details: `id: \\\"3\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Task object with id, status, and description fields.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>convert_content_body</summary>\\n\\nConverts content body from one representation format to another (storage, view, export_view, editor).\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `to` (required): Target format - `\\\"view\\\"`, `\\\"export_view\\\"`, `\\\"editor\\\"`, or `\\\"storage\\\"`\\n\\u2022 `body` (required): Content body object with value and representation fields\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `body` may be obtained from a content/body operation such as `get_content` or `create_content`.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Convert to view format: `to: \\\"view\\\", body: {\\\"value\\\": \\\"<p>Hello</p>\\\", \\\"representation\\\": \\\"storage\\\"}`\\n- Convert to editor format: `to: \\\"editor\\\", body: {\\\"value\\\": \\\"<p>Content</p>\\\", \\\"representation\\\": \\\"storage\\\"}`\\n\\n**Returns:** Converted content object with both original and converted representations.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"write-tools\\\">\\n<summary>\\u270f\\ufe0f State-Changing Tools</summary>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>create_content</summary>\\n\\nCreates a new content item (page, blogpost, comment, or attachment) in a specified space.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `body` (required): Content specification object containing:\\n  - `type` (required): Content type - `\\\"page\\\"`, `\\\"blogpost\\\"`, `\\\"comment\\\"`; `\\\"attachment\\\"` is supported but will not create a complete attachment entity with media type and links, so should be avoided\\n  - `title` (required): Content title\\n  - `spaceKey` (required): Space key where content will be created\\n  - `status` (optional, default `\\\"current\\\"`): Initial status - `\\\"current\\\"`, `\\\"draft\\\"`, `\\\"archived\\\"`, or `\\\"trashed\\\"`\\n  - `body` (optional): Content body object with:\\n    - `storage`: Object containing:\\n      - `value`: HTML content string\\n      - `representation`: Format type (should be `\\\"storage\\\"`)\\n  - `version` (optional): Version object with number and minorEdit (defaults to version 1, minorEdit false)\\n  - `postingDay` (optional): Required for blogposts - date in YYYY-MM-DD format\\n  - `ancestors` (optional): Required for comments - array of parent content IDs (strings)\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Ancestor content IDs may be retrieved from relevant content tools. Use `get_spaces` to find valid space keys.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Create simple page: `body: {\\\"type\\\": \\\"page\\\", \\\"title\\\": \\\"Meeting Notes\\\", \\\"spaceKey\\\": \\\"DOC\\\"}`\\n- Create page with content: `body: {\\\"type\\\": \\\"page\\\", \\\"title\\\": \\\"Team Page\\\", \\\"spaceKey\\\": \\\"DOC\\\", \\\"body\\\": {\\\"storage\\\": {\\\"value\\\": \\\"<p>Welcome to the team!</p>\\\", \\\"representation\\\": \\\"storage\\\"}}}`\\n- Create blog post: `body: {\\\"type\\\": \\\"blogpost\\\", \\\"title\\\": \\\"Q1 Update\\\", \\\"spaceKey\\\": \\\"BLOG\\\", \\\"postingDay\\\": \\\"2024-01-15\\\"}`\\n- Create comment: `body: {\\\"type\\\": \\\"comment\\\", \\\"title\\\": \\\"Great post!\\\", \\\"spaceKey\\\": \\\"BLOG\\\", \\\"body\\\": {\\\"storage\\\": {\\\"value\\\": \\\"<p>Thanks for sharing!</p>\\\", \\\"representation\\\": \\\"storage\\\"}}, \\\"ancestors\\\": [\\\"3\\\"]}`\\n\\n**State Changes:** Adds new content to the contents collection with auto-generated ID. Increments content_counter. Initializes version at 1 and creates history entry.\\n\\n**Returns:** Created content object with all fields including generated id, timestamps, and default values.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>update_content</summary>\\n\\nUpdates an existing content item with new data. Automatically increments version number and updates modification timestamps. Overwrites any unspecified fields.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Content ID to update\\n\\u2022 `body` (required): Updated content fields object (can include title, body, status, version, etc.)\\n\\n**Prerequisites:**\\n* The `id` must be obtained from a previous content retrieval function\\n* To preserve existing fields, first retrieve the current content with `get_content_details`, modify desired fields, then pass the updated object\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Update title: `id: \\\"1\\\", body: {\\\"title\\\": \\\"Updated Home Page\\\"}`\\n- Update content body: `id: \\\"2\\\", body: {\\\"body\\\": {\\\"storage\\\": {\\\"value\\\": \\\"<p>New content here</p>\\\", \\\"representation\\\": \\\"storage\\\"}}}`\\n- Change status: `id: \\\"3\\\", body: {\\\"status\\\": \\\"archived\\\"}`\\n- Mark as minor edit: `id: \\\"4\\\", body: {\\\"version\\\": {\\\"minorEdit\\\": true}}`\\n\\n**State Changes:** Replaces content fields in the contents collection. Increments version.number automatically. Updates modification timestamp in history.\\n\\n**Returns:** Updated content object with new version number and timestamps.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>delete_content</summary>\\n\\nDeletes content from the database. Performs soft delete (moves to trashed status) for current content, or permanent deletion for archived or draft content. Already-trashed content can be permanently deleted by using the \\\"trashed\\\" status flag.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Content ID to delete\\n\\u2022 `status` (optional): Expected current status - use `\\\"trashed\\\"` to permanently delete trashed content\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `id` must be obtained from a previous content retrieval function.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Soft delete (trash): `id: \\\"5\\\"`\\n- Permanent delete: `id: \\\"4\\\", status: \\\"trashed\\\"`\\n- Delete any status: Use without status parameter for soft delete\\n\\n**State Changes:**\\n- For soft deletion: Changes content status to \\\"trashed\\\"\\n- For permanent deletion: Permanently removes content from contents collection, also removes associated labels, properties, and attachments\\n\\n**Returns:** None (void function).\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>add_content_labels</summary>\\n\\nAdds one or more labels (tags) to a content item for categorization and discovery.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Content ID to add labels to\\n\\u2022 `labels` (required): Array of label strings to add (e.g., `[\\\"important\\\", \\\"review\\\"]`)\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `id` must be obtained from a previous content retrieval function.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Add single label: `id: \\\"1\\\", labels: [\\\"urgent\\\"]`\\n- Add multiple labels: `id: \\\"3\\\", labels: [\\\"documentation\\\", \\\"api\\\", \\\"public\\\"]`\\n- Tag for organization: `id: \\\"5\\\", labels: [\\\"team-alpha\\\", \\\"q1-2024\\\"]`\\n\\n**State Changes:** Adds labels to content_labels collection for the specified content ID. Existing labels are preserved, duplicates are avoided.\\n\\n**Returns:** Updated complete array of all labels for the content item.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>delete_content_labels</summary>\\n\\nRemoves labels from a content item. Can delete a specific label or all labels.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Content ID to remove labels from\\n\\u2022 `label` (optional): Specific label string to delete. If omitted, all labels are removed\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `id` must be obtained from a previous content retrieval function.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Remove specific label: `id: \\\"1\\\", label: \\\"draft\\\"`\\n- Remove all labels: `id: \\\"3\\\"` (omit label parameter)\\n\\n**State Changes:** Removes specified label from content_labels collection, or removes entire label array for the content if no specific label provided.\\n\\n**Returns:** None (void function).\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>create_content_property</summary>\\n\\nCreates a new custom property (key-value metadata) for a content item.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Content ID to add property to\\n\\u2022 `body` (required): Property object with:\\n  - `key` (required): Unique property key string\\n  - `value` (required): Property value (any JSON-serializable type)\\n  - `version` (optional, default 1): Property version number\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `id` must be obtained from a previous content retrieval function.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Add author property: `id: \\\"1\\\", body: {\\\"key\\\": \\\"author\\\", \\\"value\\\": \\\"Alice\\\"}`\\n- Add numeric property: `id: \\\"2\\\", body: {\\\"key\\\": \\\"views\\\", \\\"value\\\": 150}`\\n- Add complex property: `id: \\\"3\\\", body: {\\\"key\\\": \\\"metadata\\\", \\\"value\\\": {\\\"priority\\\": \\\"high\\\", \\\"team\\\": \\\"engineering\\\"}}`\\n\\n**State Changes:** Adds new property to content_properties collection with specified content ID as key. Property starts at version 1.\\n\\n**Returns:** Created property object with key, value, and version fields.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>create_content_property_for_key</summary>\\n\\nCreates a property for a specific key with version 1 requirement. Alternative to create_content_property with explicit key in path.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Content ID to add property to\\n\\u2022 `key` (required): Property key string\\n\\u2022 `body` (required): Property object with value field (version must be 1)\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `id` must be obtained from a previous content retrieval function.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Create with explicit key: `id: \\\"1\\\", key: \\\"category\\\", body: {\\\"value\\\": \\\"Tech\\\"}`\\n\\n**State Changes:** Same as create_content_property - adds property to content_properties collection.\\n\\n**Returns:** Created property object.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>update_content_property</summary>\\n\\nUpdates an existing property value for a content item. Version number must match current version and will be incremented.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Content ID containing the property\\n\\u2022 `key` (required): Property key to update\\n\\u2022 `body` (required): Updated property object with value and version fields\\n\\n**Prerequisites:**\\n* The `id` must be obtained from a previous content retrieval function\\n* The `key` must be obtained from `get_content_property` or known from previous creation\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Update property value: `id: \\\"1\\\", key: \\\"author\\\", body: {\\\"value\\\": \\\"Bob\\\", \\\"version\\\": 2}`\\n- Increment views: `id: \\\"2\\\", key: \\\"views\\\", body: {\\\"value\\\": 200, \\\"version\\\": 2}`\\n\\n**State Changes:** Updates property value in content_properties collection. Increments version number.\\n\\n**Returns:** Updated property object with new value and incremented version.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>delete_content_property</summary>\\n\\nPermanently removes a property from a content item.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Content ID containing the property\\n\\u2022 `key` (required): Property key to delete\\n\\n**Prerequisites:**\\n* The `id` must be obtained from a previous content retrieval function\\n* The `key` must be obtained from `get_content_property` or known from previous creation\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Remove property: `id: \\\"1\\\", key: \\\"author\\\"`\\n- Delete metadata: `id: \\\"3\\\", key: \\\"temporary_flag\\\"`\\n\\n**State Changes:** Removes property from content_properties collection for the specified content and key.\\n\\n**Returns:** None (void function).\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary><s>create_content_attachments</s></summary>\\n\\nAdds an attachment to a content item.\\n**Not in use - file cannot be provided.**\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Content ID to attach file to\\n\\u2022 `file` (required): File content string or filename\\n\\u2022 `minorEdit` (required): String \\\"true\\\" or \\\"false\\\" indicating if this is a minor edit\\n\\u2022 `comment` (optional): Comment string about the attachment\\n\\u2022 `status` (optional, default `\\\"current\\\"`): Attachment status\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `id` must be obtained from a previous content retrieval function.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Add document: `id: \\\"1\\\", file: \\\"document.pdf\\\", minorEdit: \\\"false\\\"`\\n- Add with comment: `id: \\\"2\\\", file: \\\"image.png\\\", minorEdit: \\\"true\\\", comment: \\\"Updated logo\\\"`\\n\\n**State Changes:** Does not correctly update state.\\n\\n**Returns:** Attachment information object with ID, filename, and comment.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>update_attachment_metadata</summary>\\n\\nUpdates attachment metadata (title, comment, labels) without changing the file content.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Content ID containing the attachment\\n\\u2022 `attachmentId` (required): Attachment ID to update\\n\\u2022 `body` (required): Updated metadata fields\\n\\n**Prerequisites:**\\n* The `id` must be obtained from a previous content retrieval function\\n* The `attachmentId` must be obtained from `get_content_attachments`\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Update attachment title: `id: \\\"1\\\", attachmentId: \\\"8\\\", body: {\\\"title\\\": \\\"New Title\\\"}`\\n- Add comment: `id: \\\"2\\\", attachmentId: \\\"9\\\", body: {\\\"comment\\\": \\\"Latest version\\\"}`\\n\\n**State Changes:** Updates attachment metadata in contents collection.\\n\\n**Returns:** Updated attachment object.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary><s>update_attachment_data</s></summary>\\n\\nUpdates the actual attachment file content (binary data) and increments version.\\n**Not in use - new file cannot be provided**\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `id` (required): Content ID containing the attachment\\n\\u2022 `attachmentId` (required): Attachment ID to update\\n\\u2022 `file` (required): New file content object\\n\\u2022 `comment` (optional): Comment about the update\\n\\u2022 `minorEdit` (optional): Boolean indicating minor edit\\n\\n**Prerequisites:**\\n* The `id` must be obtained from a previous content retrieval function\\n* The `attachmentId` must be obtained from `get_content_attachments`\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Replace file: `id: \\\"1\\\", attachmentId: \\\"8\\\", file: {...}, comment: \\\"Updated version\\\"`\\n\\n**State Changes:** Does not correctly update state.\\n\\n**Returns:** Updated attachment object with new version.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>create_space</summary>\\n\\nCreates a new public space for organizing content.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `body` (required): Space specification object with:\\n  - `name` (required): Display name for the space\\n  - `key` (optional): Unique space key (uppercase string). If not provided, alias is used\\n  - `alias` (optional): URL-friendly identifier. If not provided, key is used\\n  - `description` (optional): Space description string\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Create basic space: `body: {\\\"name\\\": \\\"Engineering Docs\\\", \\\"key\\\": \\\"ENG\\\"}`\\n- Create with description: `body: {\\\"name\\\": \\\"Marketing\\\", \\\"key\\\": \\\"MKT\\\", \\\"description\\\": \\\"Marketing team workspace\\\"}`\\n- Use alias: `body: {\\\"name\\\": \\\"Sales\\\", \\\"alias\\\": \\\"sales-team\\\"}`\\n\\n**State Changes:** Adds new space to spaces collection.\\n\\n**Returns:** Created space object with spaceKey, name, and description fields.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>create_private_space</summary>\\n\\nCreates a new private space with restricted access.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `body` (required): Space specification object with:\\n  - `key` (required): Unique space key (uppercase string)\\n  - `name` (required): Display name for the space\\n  - `description` (optional): Space description string\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Create private space: `body: {\\\"key\\\": \\\"EXEC\\\", \\\"name\\\": \\\"Executive Team\\\", \\\"description\\\": \\\"Private executive workspace\\\"}`\\n\\n**State Changes:** Adds new private space to spaces collection.\\n\\n**Returns:** Created space object with spaceKey, name, and description fields.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>update_space</summary>\\n\\nUpdates properties of an existing space (name and/or description).\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `spaceKey` (required): Space key to update\\n\\u2022 `body` (required): Updated space fields object with name and/or description\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `spaceKey` must exist (obtained from `get_spaces`).\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Update name: `spaceKey: \\\"DOC\\\", body: {\\\"name\\\": \\\"Documentation Hub\\\"}`\\n- Update description: `spaceKey: \\\"MARKETING\\\", body: {\\\"description\\\": \\\"Marketing and PR content\\\"}`\\n- Update both: `spaceKey: \\\"BLOG\\\", body: {\\\"name\\\": \\\"Company Blog\\\", \\\"description\\\": \\\"Official announcements\\\"}`\\n\\n**State Changes:** Updates space fields in spaces collection.\\n\\n**Returns:** Updated space object.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>delete_space</summary>\\n\\nDeletes a space and all its content. Creates a deleted space task to mock tracking the deletion progress.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `spaceKey` (required): Space key to delete\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** The `spaceKey` must exist (obtained from `get_spaces`).\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Delete old space: `spaceKey: \\\"ARCHIVE\\\"`\\n- Remove test space: `spaceKey: \\\"TEST\\\"`\\n\\n**State Changes:**\\n- Removes space from spaces collection\\n- Cascades deletion to all content in that space (removes from contents collection)\\n- Creates deletion task in deleted_spaces_tasks collection (set automatically to \\\"compelete\\\")\\n- Removes associated labels and properties for deleted content\\n\\n**Returns:** Task object tracking the deletion operation with id, status, and description.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:** A long-running task will be created for the deletion of the space, but it will not be able to be used in-world for tracking purposes - it is immediately set to \\\"complete\\\". This cannot be altered.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n</details>\\n\"\n                }\n                ,\n                {\n                    name: \"hubspot\",\n                    componentName: \"Hubspot\",\n                    propsJson: {\"database\": {}, \"timezoneOffset\": \"-05:00\"},\n                    propsJsonPrev: null,\n                    bundleUrl: \"https://agent-tools-11866-a72f0a4c-vrd7x608.onporter.run/static/bundle.js\",\n                    docsRaw: \"\"\n                }\n                ,\n                {\n                    name: \"clock\",\n                    componentName: \"Clock\",\n                    propsJson: {\"database\": {\"settings\": {\"default_alarm_sound\": \"Sonic Pulse\", \"default_timer_sound\": \"Digital Beep\", \"snooze_duration\": 300, \"time_format\": \"12_hour\", \"alarm_volume\": 0.9, \"timer_volume\": 0.8, \"show_seconds\": false}, \"alarms\": {\"ALARM-1\": {\"state\": \"ACTIVE\", \"label\": \"ECHO Weekly Rollout\", \"date\": \"2026-01-05\", \"alarm_id\": \"ALARM-1\", \"created_at\": \"2026-01-01T09:00:00Z\", \"fire_time\": \"2026-01-05T09:00:00Z\", \"time_of_day\": \"9:00 AM\", \"recurrence\": \"MONDAY\"}}, \"timers\": {}, \"stopwatch\": {\"lap_times\": [], \"pause_time\": null, \"start_time\": null, \"state\": \"STOPPED\", \"elapsed_time\": 0}}, \"timezoneOffset\": \"-05:00\"},\n                    propsJsonPrev: null,\n                    bundleUrl: \"https://agent-tools-11866-a72f0a4c-vrd7x608.onporter.run/static/bundle.js\",\n                    docsRaw: \"<style>\\ndetails summary {\\n    padding: 8px;\\n    border-radius: 4px;\\n    margin: 4px 0;\\n    cursor: pointer;\\n    font-weight: bold;\\n}\\ndetails[open] {\\n    border: 1px solid #ddd;\\n    border-radius: 4px;\\n    padding: 8px;\\n    margin: 8px 0;\\n}\\ndetails details {\\n    margin-left: 16px;\\n    border-left: 2px solid #ddd;\\n    padding-left: 8px;\\n}\\n.overview { background-color: #d8eeffff; }\\n.documentation { background-color: #fbe9ffff; }\\n.data-structure { background-color: #fbefffff; border-left: 3px solid #6c757d; }\\n.read-tools { background-color: #dcffe0ff; }\\n.write-tools { background-color: #ffe8c2ff; }\\n.tool { background-color: #f8f9fa; border-left: 3px solid #6c757d; }\\n</style>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"overview\\\">\\n<summary>\\ud83d\\udd0d Service Overview</summary>\\n\\nThe Clock service represents the alarms, timers, and a stopwatch on the user's device. It can track and modify multiple concurrent alarms and timers, and a single stopwatch with lap functionality.\\n\\n**Key Features:**\\n* **Alarms:**\\n    \\u2022 Can be scheduled with a custom label for a certain date and time.\\n    \\u2022 Can be set to repeat on certain days of the week.\\n    \\u2022 Can be enabled, disabled, actively going off, cancelled, snoozed, or deleted.\\n\\n* **Timers:**\\n    \\u2022 Can have a set duration.\\n    \\u2022 Can be currently running, with a remaining duration.\\n    \\u2022 Can be paused, running, reset, cancelled, stopped, finished, resumed, or deleted.\\n    \\u2022 Can have a custom label.\\n\\n* **Stopwatch:**\\n    \\u2022 There is only one stopwatch at a time.\\n    \\u2022 Can be running, paused, or stopped.\\n    \\u2022 Can have a currently elapsed time, in seconds.\\n    \\u2022 Can have a list of previous lap times, in seconds.\\n\\n**Clock Settings will be configured in initial context but the agent cannot use them in these tasks (no read or write access).**\\n\\n**High-Level Usage Patterns:**\\n- Create alarms with specific times and optional recurrence patterns (daily, weekdays, specific days)\\n- Create timers with durations or specific fire times\\n- Search and filter alarms or timers by time, label, date range, or state\\n- Modify alarms and timers individually or in bulk (time, date, label, recurrence, etc.)\\n- Control alarm and timer states (enabled/running/snoozed/stopped etc.)\\n- Use stopwatch for continuous timing with lap tracking\\n\\n**Default Example DB Overview:**\\nThe example DB contains 5 pre-configured alarms (including morning alarm, meeting reminders, and recurring work alarms), 4 timers in various states (running, paused, finished, reset), and a stopped stopwatch. Each alarm and timer has a unique ID, timestamps, labels, and state indicators.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"documentation\\\">\\n<summary>\\ud83d\\udcda Detailed Documentation</summary>\\n\\n## Core Concepts\\n\\n### Alarms\\nAlarms fire at scheduled times, either as one-time events or recurring on specific days of the week. Each alarm tracks its state (ACTIVE, FIRING, SNOOZED, DISABLED) and can be temporarily cancelled.\\nSnoozing updates the fire_time and changes state to SNOOZED, with a default of 10 minutes (600 seconds) if no duration is specified; if you snooze to a time in the past, it automatically advances to the next day.\\nRecurring alarms reset automatically after firing.\\n\\n### Timers\\nTimers count down from a specified duration to zero, tracking both original and remaining time.\\nThey support standard operations like pause (preserving remaining time), resume, reset (restore original duration), and complete (FINISHED state).\\n\\n### Stopwatch\\nThe stopwatch measures elapsed time supporting start, pause, and reset operations. Lap recording captures both cumulative elapsed time and split time between laps. The stopwatch maintains lap history with timestamps.\\n\\n**Clock settings are not currently viewable or modifiable by the agent.**\\n\\n<details class=\\\"data-structure\\\">\\n<summary>Database Structure</summary>\\nThe Clock database has four root collections: one for each type of clock object, and one for the service's settings.\\n\\n<details class=\\\"data-structure\\\">\\n<summary>ClockAlarm Object</summary>\\nEach alarm in the alarms collection (keyed by alarm_id like \\\"ALARM-1\\\") is a `ClockAlarm` object with the following fields:\\n\\n* `alarm_id`: (Required) Unique identifier for the alarm. Format: \\\"ALARM-{number}\\\" (e.g., \\\"ALARM-1\\\", \\\"ALARM-2\\\")\\n\\n* `time_of_day`: (Required) Time of day when the alarm fires, in 12-hour format with AM/PM (e.g., \\\"7:00 AM\\\", \\\"2:30 PM\\\")\\n\\n* `date`: (Required) Date the alarm is scheduled for, in YYYY-MM-DD format (e.g., \\\"2024-01-15\\\")\\n\\n* `label`: (Required) Label for the alarm. Can be empty string `\\\"\\\"` for unlabeled alarms (e.g., \\\"Morning alarm\\\", \\\"Meeting reminder\\\", \\\"\\\")\\n\\n* `state`: (Required) Current state of the alarm. Valid values:\\n    * `ACTIVE`: Alarm is enabled and will fire at scheduled time\\n    * `DISABLED`: Alarm is turned off and will not fire\\n    * `SNOOZED`: Alarm was snoozed and will fire again after snooze duration\\n    * `CANCELLED`: Alarm was cancelled\\n    * `FIRING`: Alarm is currently going off\\n\\n* `recurrence`: (Required) Recurrence pattern. Can be:\\n    * Empty string `\\\"\\\"` for one-time alarms\\n    * Comma-separated day names for recurring alarms (e.g., \\\"MONDAY,TUESDAY,WEDNESDAY,THURSDAY,FRIDAY\\\", \\\"SATURDAY,SUNDAY\\\")\\n\\n* `created_at`: (Required) ISO 8601 timestamp when alarm was created (e.g., \\\"2024-01-14T22:30:00\\\")\\n\\n* `fire_time`: (Required) ISO 8601 timestamp when alarm is set to fire (e.g., \\\"2024-01-15T07:00:00\\\")\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"data-structure\\\">\\n<summary>ClockTimer Object</summary>\\nEach timer in the timers collection (keyed by timer_id like \\\"TIMER-1\\\") is a `ClockTimer` object with the following fields:\\n\\n* `timer_id`: (Required) Unique identifier for the timer. Format: \\\"TIMER-{number}\\\" (e.g., \\\"TIMER-1\\\", \\\"TIMER-2\\\")\\n\\n* `original_duration`: (Required) Original duration of the timer in format `{hours}h{minutes}m{seconds}s`. Components are optional but at least one must be present (e.g., \\\"25m\\\", \\\"5h30m20s\\\", \\\"2h\\\", \\\"45s\\\", \\\"1h15m\\\")\\n\\n* `remaining_duration`: (Required) Remaining duration on the timer. Same format as `original_duration`. For finished timers, this is \\\"0s\\\" (e.g., \\\"18m30s\\\", \\\"10m\\\", \\\"0s\\\")\\n\\n* `time_of_day`: (Required) Time when timer will go off, in 12-hour format with AM/PM (e.g., \\\"2:45 PM\\\", \\\"11:30 AM\\\")\\n\\n* `label`: (Required) Label for the timer. Can be empty string `\\\"\\\"` for unlabeled timers (e.g., \\\"Pomodoro session\\\", \\\"Tea brewing\\\", \\\"\\\")\\n\\n* `state`: (Required) Current state of the timer. Valid values:\\n    * `RUNNING`: Timer is actively counting down\\n    * `PAUSED`: Timer is paused\\n    * `FINISHED`: Timer has completed and reached zero\\n    * `RESET`: Timer has been reset\\n    * `CANCELLED`: Timer was cancelled\\n    * `STOPPED`: Timer was stopped\\n\\n* `created_at`: (Required) ISO 8601 timestamp when timer was created (e.g., \\\"2024-01-15T14:20:00\\\")\\n\\n* `fire_time`: (Required) ISO 8601 timestamp when timer will fire (e.g., \\\"2024-01-15T14:45:00\\\")\\n\\n* `start_time`: (Required) ISO 8601 timestamp when timer was started (e.g., \\\"2024-01-15T14:20:00\\\")\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"data-structure\\\">\\n<summary>ClockStopwatch Object</summary>\\nThere is a single stopwatch object with the following fields:\\n\\n* `state`: (Required) Current state of the stopwatch. Valid values:\\n    * `STOPPED`: Stopwatch is stopped/reset at zero\\n    * `RUNNING`: Stopwatch is actively timing\\n    * `PAUSED`: Stopwatch is paused at a specific elapsed time\\n\\n* `start_time`: (Optional) ISO 8601 timestamp when stopwatch was started. Can be `null` when stopwatch is stopped or paused (e.g., \\\"2024-01-15T14:30:00\\\", `null`)\\n\\n* `pause_time`: (Optional) ISO 8601 timestamp when stopwatch was paused. Can be `null` when stopwatch is stopped or running (e.g., \\\"2024-01-15T14:35:00\\\", `null`)\\n\\n* `elapsed_time`: (Required) Elapsed time in seconds as a non-negative integer. For RUNNING stopwatch, this is dynamically calculated. For PAUSED, this is the frozen value. For STOPPED, this is 0 (e.g., 0, 125, 3600)\\n\\n* `lap_times`: (Required) Array of `LapTime` objects recording each lap. Empty array `[]` when no laps have been recorded\\n\\n<details class=\\\"data-structure\\\">\\n<summary>LapTime Object</summary>\\nEach entry in the stopwatch's `lap_times` array is a `LapTime` object with the following fields:\\n\\n* `lap_number`: (Required) Sequential lap number, starting from 1 (e.g., 1, 2, 3)\\n\\n* `lap_time`: (Required) Total elapsed time in seconds at the moment this lap was recorded, as a non-negative integer (e.g., 45, 125, 180)\\n\\n* `lap_duration`: (Required) Human-readable duration string for the total elapsed time at this lap (e.g., \\\"45s\\\", \\\"2m5s\\\", \\\"3m\\\")\\n\\n* `split_time`: (Required) Time in seconds since the previous lap (or since start for lap 1), as a non-negative integer. This is the duration of this specific lap (e.g., 45, 80, 55)\\n\\n* `split_duration`: (Required) Human-readable duration string for the split time (e.g., \\\"45s\\\", \\\"1m20s\\\", \\\"55s\\\")\\n\\n* `timestamp`: (Required) ISO 8601 timestamp when this lap was recorded (e.g., \\\"2024-01-15T14:30:45\\\")\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n\\n<details class=\\\"data-structure\\\">\\n<summary>ClockSettings Object</summary>\\nThe settings object contains clock application configuration.\\n\\n**The agent cannot view or edit Clock Settings, and their values may not be reflected in the UI**\\n\\n* `default_alarm_sound`: (Required) Default sound for alarms (e.g., \\\"gentle_chime\\\", \\\"bell\\\")\\n\\n* `default_timer_sound`: (Required) Default sound for timers (e.g., \\\"bell\\\", \\\"buzzer\\\")\\n\\n* `snooze_duration`: (Required) Default snooze duration in seconds, must be a positive integer \\u22651 (e.g., 600 for 10 minutes, 300 for 5 minutes) **NOT USED. The snooze tools will not apply the value entered here, and will use 600s (10min) as default.**\\n\\n* `alarm_volume`: (Required) Alarm volume as a number between 0.0 and 1.0 inclusive (e.g., 0.8, 0.5, 1.0)\\n\\n* `timer_volume`: (Required) Timer volume as a number between 0.0 and 1.0 inclusive (e.g., 0.7, 0.5, 1.0)\\n\\n* `time_format`: (Required) Time display format. Valid values:\\n    * `12_hour`: 12-hour format with AM/PM\\n    * `24_hour`: 24-hour military time format\\n\\n* `show_seconds`: (Required) Whether to show seconds in time display, as a boolean (e.g., `true`, `false`)\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"read-tools\\\">\\n<summary>\\ud83d\\udcd6 Read-Only Tools</summary>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>show_matching_alarms</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves alarms matching specified criteria. Returns a list of alarm objects with their current state and configuration.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `query` (optional): Either exact time or label of alarm (case insensitive). Time accepts both 12-hour (\\\"7:00 AM\\\") and 24-hour (\\\"14:30\\\") formats. Labels support simple text search with space-separated terms where all keywords must be present to find a match. Does not support boolean operators (OR, NOT), wildcards, or special syntax.\\n\\u2022 `alarm_type` (optional): Filter by alarm type - \\\"UPCOMING\\\" (scheduled for future), \\\"ACTIVE\\\" (will fire or currently firing), \\\"DISABLED\\\" (inactive states)\\n\\u2022 `alarm_ids` (optional): Array of specific alarm IDs to retrieve (e.g., [\\\"ALARM-1\\\", \\\"ALARM-3\\\"])\\n\\u2022 `date` (optional): Filter by specific date in YYYY-MM-DD format\\n\\u2022 `start_date` (optional): Filter for alarms on or after this date (YYYY-MM-DD)\\n\\u2022 `end_date` (optional): Filter for alarms on or before this date (YYYY-MM-DD)\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Find all morning alarms: `query: \\\"7:00 AM\\\"`\\n- Show alarms with label containing \\\"meeting\\\": `query: \\\"meeting\\\"`\\n- Find alarms with both keywords (AND): `query: \\\"team meeting\\\"` (matches \\\"team meeting reminder\\\", \\\"meeting for team\\\", etc.)\\n- List all upcoming alarms: `alarm_type: \\\"UPCOMING\\\"`\\n- View disabled alarms: `alarm_type: \\\"DISABLED\\\"`\\n- Check alarms for specific date: `date: \\\"2024-01-15\\\"`\\n- Find alarms in date range: `start_date: \\\"2024-01-15\\\", end_date: \\\"2024-01-20\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Message with count of matching alarms and array of alarm objects containing alarm_id, time_of_day, date, label, state, recurrence, and fire_time.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>show_matching_timers</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves timers matching specified criteria. Automatically updates remaining_duration for running timers based on current time.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `query` (optional): Duration (\\\"10m\\\", \\\"1h30m\\\"), time (\\\"9:30\\\", \\\"14:00\\\"), or label of timer (case insensitive). Tries parsing as duration first, then time, then label. Labels support simple text search with space-separated terms where all keywords must be present to find a match. Does not support boolean operators (OR, NOT), wildcards, or special syntax.\\n\\u2022 `timer_type` (optional): Filter by type - \\\"UPCOMING\\\" (scheduled for future), \\\"RUNNING\\\" (actively counting), \\\"PAUSED\\\" (stopped, cancelled, reset, or paused)\\n\\u2022 `timer_ids` (optional): Array of specific timer IDs to retrieve (e.g., [\\\"TIMER-1\\\", \\\"TIMER-2\\\"])\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Find 10-minute timers: `query: \\\"10m\\\"`\\n- Show running timers: `timer_type: \\\"RUNNING\\\"`\\n- Find paused timers: `timer_type: \\\"PAUSED\\\"`\\n- Search by label: `query: \\\"cooking\\\"`\\n- Find timers with both keywords (AND): `query: \\\"tea brewing\\\"` (matches labels containing both \\\"tea\\\" and \\\"brewing\\\")\\n- Get specific timers: `timer_ids: [\\\"TIMER-1\\\"]`\\n\\n**Returns:** Message with count of matching timers and array of timer objects containing timer_id, original_duration, remaining_duration (dynamically calculated for running timers), time_of_day, label, state, and fire_time.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>show_stopwatch</summary>\\n\\nDisplays current stopwatch state including elapsed time and lap count. Updates elapsed time in real-time for running stopwatch.\\n\\n**Parameters:** None\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Check if stopwatch is running\\n- View total elapsed time\\n- See how many laps have been recorded\\n- Verify stopwatch state before operations\\n\\n**Returns:** Message indicating stopwatch state (stopped/running/paused), elapsed time in format \\\"Xh Ym Zs\\\", and lap count if laps exist.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"write-tools\\\">\\n<summary>\\u270f\\ufe0f State-Changing Tools</summary>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>create_alarm</summary>\\n\\nCreates a new alarm with specified time, date, and optional recurrence pattern. Generates unique alarm ID automatically.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `duration` (optional): Duration from now (e.g., \\\"15m\\\", \\\"2h30m\\\"). Format: \\\"{hours}h{minutes}m{seconds}s\\\"\\n\\u2022 `time` (optional): Specific time of day. Accepts 24-hour (\\\"14:30\\\") or 12-hour (\\\"2:30 PM\\\") formats\\n\\u2022 `date` (optional): Scheduled date in YYYY-MM-DD format. If omitted with time, uses today or tomorrow\\n\\u2022 `label` (optional): Descriptive label for alarm identification\\n\\u2022 `recurrence` (optional): Array of days like [\\\"MONDAY\\\", \\\"FRIDAY\\\"]. Case insensitive. Valid: SUNDAY through SATURDAY\\n- NOTE: Must provide either duration OR time (if both, duration takes precedence)\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** None\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Quick alarm in 15 minutes: `duration: \\\"15m\\\"`\\n- Morning alarm at 7 AM: `time: \\\"7:00 AM\\\", label: \\\"Wake up\\\"`\\n- Recurring weekday alarm: `time: \\\"8:30\\\", recurrence: [\\\"MONDAY\\\", \\\"TUESDAY\\\", \\\"WEDNESDAY\\\", \\\"THURSDAY\\\", \\\"FRIDAY\\\"]`\\n- Specific date alarm: `time: \\\"14:00\\\", date: \\\"2024-02-14\\\", label: \\\"Valentine's Day reminder\\\"`\\n- Tomorrow at specific time: `time: \\\"10:30 PM\\\"` (will be next day if current time past 10:30 PM)\\n\\n**State Changes:** Adds new alarm to alarms dictionary with generated ALARM-{N} ID, state set to ACTIVE, calculates fire_time based on duration/time/date parameters, stores created_at timestamp.\\n\\n**Returns:** Success message with alarm time and single-item array containing the new alarm object with alarm_id, time_of_day, date, label, state, recurrence, and fire_time.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>modify_alarm_v2</summary>\\n\\nModifies one or multiple alarms' properties including time, date, label, recurrence, or state. Supports filtering and bulk operations.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `filters` (optional): Dictionary to identify alarms. Keys: `time` (string), `label` (string), `date_range` (dict with start_date/end_date), `alarm_type` (string), `alarm_ids` (array)\\n\\u2022 `modifications` (optional): Dictionary specifying changes.
